title: Asteroids Ship

steps.hint: Asteroids (1979) was one of the first games of the shoot-em-up genre. It was set in space so we're going to need to set the scene **type** `background black`

The graphics in Asteroids were simple line based graphics called vectors, we still use a more complex version of this concept in computer graphics today. First we need to set our line colour and width **type** `stroke white,5`
Next we use the move function to set the starting point for our first line. **type** `move 0, -70`
We use the line function to draw a line relative to our starting position, we use a negative number first to move to the left and a positive number second to move downward **type** `line -50,150`
To move our cursor to the start of the next line we feed the previous coordinates into the move function. **type** `move -50,150`
We draw a line inwards and upwards to form the thruster of the ship **type** `line 50,-25`
Again moving to the same coordinates for a continuous line **type** `move 50,-25`
We replicate the shape for the right side of the ship by reversing the second coordinate to draw downwards instead of up **type** `line 50,25`
Follow through with the line again **type** `move 50,25`
Our ship starts to take shape **type** `line -50,-150`
Finally we move back to our starting point to add a final touch **type** `move -50,-150`

We draw a line down the centre to help the simple shape look more like a ship, early videogames had only a fraction of computing power we are used to today, so graphics had to be basic. **type** `line 0,125`

completion_text: It might not look like much but simple graphics like this were where videogames we know today began and games like this lay the foundations for the 3D graphics we're used to today.
